summary: Nitric oxide (NO) is a colorless gas with an unpaired electron, making it a free radical. It's found in nature, formed during combustion, and even produced by lightning. This molecule is crucial in industrial chemistry and has various applications. In the human body, it acts as a signaling molecule, important for blood vessel function and other processes. NO's significance was recognized with the 1998 Nobel Prize in Medicine. It's also used in medicine, like in Viagra, and in industry, such as making semiconductors. Remember, it's different from nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and nitrous oxide (N2O).
title: Nitric oxide
